The cells of Desulfosporosinus hippei DSM 8344 are rod-shaped and motile. They can grow at temperatures ranging from 10°C to 40°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 30°C. The bacterium is capable of utilizing a variety of organic compounds, such as lactate, pyruvate, and ethanol, as electron donors for sulfate reduction.

Phylogenetically, Desulfosporosinus hippei DSM 8344 belongs to the genus Desulfosporosinus, which is a member of the Firmicutes phylum. The species was first isolated and described in 1997 by researchers and named after the German microbiologist Dieter Höppe.

This sulfate-reducing bacterium is of interest due to its potential role in biogeochemical cycling of sulfur in various environments, as well as its potential applications in bioremediation of sulfate-contaminated sites and the production of hydrogen as a biofuel.
